What is the intent of the Singleton pattern?;Ensure a class has only one instance and provide a global access point to it.;100;0;0;The intent of the Singleton pattern is to ensure that a class has only one instance and to provide a global point of access to that instance. This is crucial for certain classes that should maintain a single instance
column2: such as a printer spooler or a file system. The pattern achieves this by restricting the instantiation of the class and typically involves a static member function that controls the creation of the instance
column3: ensuring that only one instance exists throughout the application.;100;0;0;

column1: What problems does the Factory Method pattern solve and in which scenario from the PDF is its use exemplified?;"Allows defining an interface for creating an object but lets subclasses decide which concrete class to instantiate; used in frameworks/toolkits where the base code delegates creation to subclasses (e.g.
column2: controller creation in MVC).";100;0;0;The Factory Method pattern solves the problem of instantiating objects when the exact type of the object is not known until runtime. It encapsulates the knowledge of which subclass to create
column3: allowing the framework to remain flexible and extensible. In the PDF
column4: the scenario exemplifying its use involves an Application class that cannot predict which subclass of Document to instantiate. Instead
column5: the Factory Method allows the Application to create Document objects without needing to know their specific types
column6: thus promoting loose coupling and adherence to the Open/Closed Principle.;100;0;0;

column1: According to the PDF
column2: what is the main trade-off when deciding whether to declare child management operations (Add/Remove) in Component vs Composite in the Composite pattern?;"Transparency vs. safety: declaring operations in Component gives transparency (treating all uniformly) but reduces safety; declaring them only in Composite gives safety but loses transparency.";100;0;0;The main trade-off when deciding whether to declare child management operations (Add/Remove) in Component vs Composite in the Composite pattern is between safety and transparency. Declaring these operations at the root of the class hierarchy (Component) provides transparency
column3: allowing uniform treatment of all components. However
column4: this can lead to safety issues
column5: as clients might attempt to perform invalid operations on leaf nodes. Conversely
column6: defining these operations in the Composite class enhances safety by preventing invalid operations at compile-time
column7: but it sacrifices transparency since leaves and composites will have different interfaces.;100;0;0;

column1: Which pattern from the PDF would you recommend to easily swap caching policies in a subsystem
column2: and why?;Strategy: encapsulates algorithms (caching policies) in interchangeable objects
column3: allowing the policy to vary without changing clients.;100;0;0;I recommend using the **Strategy pattern** from the PDF to easily swap caching policies in a subsystem. The Strategy pattern allows for encapsulating algorithms (in this case
column4: caching policies) in separate classes
column5: enabling you to vary the caching strategy independently of the subsystem's context. This flexibility makes it easier to switch between different caching policies without modifying the subsystem's core logic

column1: According to the PDF
column2: what advantage does Abstract Factory offer regarding consistency among products?;It isolates concrete classes and makes it easier to use objects from a single coherent family (promotes consistency among products of the same family).;100;0;0;The Abstract Factory pattern offers the advantage of promoting consistency among products by ensuring that an application uses objects from only one family at a time. This enforcement helps maintain compatibility among the products created
column3: as they are designed to work together. By encapsulating a group of individual factories that share a common theme
column4: the Abstract Factory guarantees a uniform interface for the products
column5: thus enhancing consistency across different product families.;50;0;50;

column1: Which pattern from the PDF is suggested to reduce storage costs when there are many fine-grained objects?;Flyweight: reuses shared state to reduce storage cost for many fine-grained objects.;100;0;0;The Flyweight pattern is suggested to reduce storage costs when there are many fine-grained objects. This pattern is particularly effective when an application uses a large number of objects
column2: storage costs are high due to the quantity of objects
column3: and most object state can be made extrinsic. By sharing objects and removing extrinsic state
column4: the application can significantly decrease the number of distinct objects

Which tests would you include to evaluate source attribution of your RAG when answering questions about design patterns?;"Scenario: pose questions about concrete pattern examples; measure if the RAG cites PDF chunks (DesignPatterns) correctly and if
column2: for concrete code
column3: it cites the file/line in GitHub; evaluate coverage and accuracy of source traces (precision/recall of cited sources).";50;40;10;"To evaluate source attribution of your RAG when answering questions about design patterns
column4: you should include the following tests:

column1: 1. **Document Relevance:** Ensure that the retrieved documents consistently address the user's inquiries about design patterns.
2. **Answer Accuracy:** Verify that the outputs accurately reflect the information in the retrieved documents
column2: comparing them to established facts or having knowledgeable reviewers assess them.

column1: 3. **Hallucination Checks:** Monitor for any incorrect details introduced by the RAG system that are not found in the retrieved documents
column2: ensuring answers are grounded in the provided sources.

column1: 4. **Contextual Recall:** Confirm that the retrieval context contains all necessary information to produce ideal outputs for specific inputs regarding design patterns.
5. **Contextual Precision:** Ensure that relevant text chunks are prioritized over irrelevant ones
column2: focusing on the most important information about design patterns.

column1: 6. **Task Completion:** Test whether the AI can access the correct tools with appropriate arguments to complete tasks effectively.
These tests align with the principles outlined in the design patterns literature
column2: emphasizing the importance of critical evaluation and accurate representation of design concepts.";40;0;60;

column1: Which section of the PDF contains the explanation of Template Method and what is the central idea it proposes?;"The catalog of patterns section (behavioral chapter); Template Method defines the skeleton of an algorithm in an operation and delegates steps to subclasses.";100;0;0;"The explanation of the Template Method can be found in the PDF document starting from section 301. The central idea it proposes is that the Template Method allows subclasses to redefine certain steps of an algorithm without altering the overall structure of the algorithm. This pattern promotes an inverted control structure
column2: where the parent class calls the operations of the subclass
column3: embodying the principle of ""Don't call us
column4: we'll call you.""";100;0;0;

column1: Which pattern is suitable to represent states with objects and why?;State: represents each state as an object
column2: allowing the context's behavior to change when the object representing the state changes.;100;0;0;The State pattern is suitable for representing states with objects because it allows an object to alter its behavior when its internal state changes
column3: effectively making it appear as if the object has changed its class. This pattern encapsulates the various states of an object
column4: enabling it to respond differently based on its current state. For example
column5: a `TCPConnection` object can be in states like Established
column8: and its response to requests varies depending on its state. This encapsulation enhances flexibility and reusability in design
column9: as state objects can be shared and managed efficiently.;100;0;0;

column1: Which pattern from the PDF would you recommend to expose a simple interface over a complex subsystem (e.g.
column2: analytics wrapper in the repo) and why?;Facade: provides a unified
column3: simplified interface to a set of interfaces in a subsystem
column4: hiding complexity.;100;0;0;I recommend using the **Facade pattern** to expose a simple interface over a complex subsystem
column5: such as an analytics wrapper. The Facade pattern is specifically designed to provide a simplified interface to a complex subsystem
column6: making it easier for clients to interact with the system without needing to understand its intricacies. This is particularly useful as subsystems can become more complex over time
column7: and the Facade can offer a default view that simplifies usage for clients who do not require customization.;100;0;0;

column1: Combine GitHub + PDF: 'How would you apply Decorator (PDF) to add logging metrics to the ingestion pipeline (repo) without modifying base classes?' Expected answer.;"Use Decorator to wrap pipeline components (e.g.
column2: extractor or vectorizer) with objects that add logging/metrics behavior before and after calling the underlying component; this extends functionality without changing base classes in the repo's pipeline.";65;30;5;To apply the Decorator pattern for adding logging metrics to the ingestion pipeline without modifying base classes
column3: you would create a logging decorator that wraps the existing ingestion components. This decorator would implement the same interface as the base ingestion class
column4: allowing it to be used interchangeably. Inside the decorator
column5: you would add the logging functionality before and after calling the methods of the wrapped ingestion component. This approach allows you to enhance the functionality dynamically without altering the original classes
column6: adhering to the principles of the Decorator pattern as described in the PDF.;100;0;0;
